text: # Onboarding
Once upon a time there was an old king who was so ill...<ins>Swipe card to make a choice...</ins>
left_text: Could I do something?
right_text: Is he going to get better?

text: I am dying, Trusty John... You have served me so faithfully for all my life<ins>Your decisions influence the scores you see above</ins>
left_text: What is going to happen to the kingdom
right_text: Who's going to take care of me now?

text: I could face my end without a care were it not for my son. He is still too young to decide everything for himself<ins>Keep the scores balanced, don't let them grow or dwindle</ins>
left_text: He shall be our new King
right_text: He's a troublemaker

text: Unless you promise me to instruct him in all he should know, and to be to him as a father, I shall not close my eyes in peace<ins>Swipe right to continue...</ins>
left_text: Uhmmm
right_text: As you say, mylord

text: You must promise me<ins>Swipe right to continue...</ins>
left_text: Not sure
right_text: Be assured, my king

text: # Old king
Now I die comforted and in peace. After my death you must show him the whole castle, all the rooms and apartments and vaults, and all the treasures that lie in them
left_text: So be it, your majesty
right_text: You have my word, your highness

text: but you must not show him the last room in the long passage, where the picture of the Princess of the Golden Roof is hidden. When he beholds that picture he will fall violently in love with it and go off into a dead faint, and for her sake he will encounter many dangers; you must guard him from this
left_text: I promise, mylord
right_text: I will do as you say, my king

text: the old man became silent, laid his head on the pillow, and died.
left_text: Let him rest in peace
right_text: It was an honour serving him. Long live his name

text: # New king
When the old King had been carried to his grave and when the time of mourning was over
left_text: It is time you should see your inheritance. I will show you your ancestral castle
right_text: I shall be faithful to you as I have been to him, even though it should cost me my life

text: You take him over everything, and let him see all the riches and splendid apartments, only the one room where the picture was he did not open. But the young King noticed that Trusty John always missed one door, and said: "Why do you never open this one for me?"
left_text: There is something inside that would appall you
right_text: As you wish

text: I have seen the whole castle, and shall find out what is in there. I will force it open
left_text: I promised your father before his death that you shouldn't see what that room contains
right_text: Okay

text: Ah! no, if I don't get in, it will be my certain destruction; I should have no peace night or day till I had seen what was in the room with my own eyes
left_text: It might bring both you and me to great grief
right_text: As you command

text: Now I don't budge from the spot till you have opened the door.
left_text: With heavy heart I must do it
right_text: I will do as you say

text: # Secret room
Then you saw there was no way out of it, so with a heavy heart and many sighs you took the key from the big bunch...
left_text: Just be careful, Mylord
right_text: You have left me with no choice

text: When you had opened the door you stepped in first, and thought to cover the likeness so that the King might not perceive it; but it was hopeless...<ins>Sometimes all that remains to you is to let things go</ins>
The King stood on tiptoe and looked over his shoulder. And when he saw the picture of the maid, so beautiful and glittering with gold and precious stones, he fell swooning to the ground.
left_text: I will take care of it My King, just stay with me
right_text: Wake up, Mylord, don't leave me alone

text: The King came to himself, but only after you poured wine down his throat
left_text: Oh, My King, allow me to take care of you
right_text: Thank God, everything is fine

text: Oh! who is the original of the beautiful picture?
left_text: I have no idea
right_text: She is the Princess of the Golden Roof

text: My love for her is so great that if all the leaves on the trees had tongues they could not express it; my very life depends on my winning her. You are my most trusty John: you must stand by me
# Making plan
The faithful servant pondered long how they were to set about the matter, for it was said to be difficult even to get into the presence of the Princess.
left_text: You have in your treasure five tons of gold and the goldsmiths of your kingdom are skillful and famous
right_text: All the things she has about her are made of gold. We shall bring to her your treasures and try our luck with them

text: All the things she has about her are made of gold. I can order my goldsmiths to make all manners of vases and vessels
left_text: We shall bring to her your treasures and try our luck with them
right_text: We shall bring to her your treasures and try to win her over with them

text: So she likes gold. I have five tons of gold and the goldsmiths of my kingdom are legendary masters
left_text: Let them the gold into all manner of vases and vessels
right_text: Let them the gold into all sorts of birds and game and wonderful beasts

text: The King summoned all his goldsmiths, and they had to work hard day and night, till at length the most magnificent things were completed.
When a ship had been laden with them the faithful John disguised himself as a merchant, and the King had to do the same, so that they should be quite unrecognizable.
And so they crossed the seas and journeyed till they reached the town where the Princess of the Golden Roof dwelt.
left_text: Mylord, I will go for the princes, but you must wait on the ship
right_text: Stay on the ship, My King, and await for my return

text: # Ship parts
Bring back the princess and I will let the gold ornaments be arranged and the whole ship decorated
left_text: I will take a few of the gold things in my apron, and proceed straight to the palace
right_text: I will take some gold things straight to the palace

text: When you came to the courtyard, there is a beautiful maiden standing at the well, drawing water with two golden pails
And as she was about to carry away the glittering water she turned round and saw you with your gold and asked you who you were
left_text: I'm a servant who has come to invite your Princess to my King
right_text: I am a merchant

text: Oh! my, what beautiful gold wares! Let me set down my pails, and examine your gold items one thing after the other
left_text: These are the goods I sell
right_text: Let me show these goods to your Mistress

text: The Princess must see this, she has such a fancy for gold things that she will buy up all you have
left_text: Very well, take me to her
right_text: It will be my pleasure to show them to her

text: They are all so beautifully made that I shall buy everything you have
left_text: I am only the servant of a rich merchant, his merchandise is more artistic and costly than anything that has ever been made in gold before
right_text: What I have here is nothing compared to what my master has on his ship. There is such a quantity of things that they would take up so many rooms that you would have no space for them in your house

text: Take me to your ship; I shall go there myself and view your master's treasures
# Sail back

Then Trusty John was quite delighted, and brought her to the ship; and the King, when he beheld her, saw that she was even more beautiful than her picture, and thought every moment that his heart would burst.
She stepped on to the ship, and the King led her inside. You John remained behind with the steersman, and ordered
left_text: Push off the ship silently like a shadow in the night
right_text: Spread all sail, that we may fly on the ocean like a bird in the air

text: Meanwhile the King showed the Princess inside all his gold wares, every single bit of it--dishes, goblets, bowls, the birds and game, and all the wonderful beasts. Many hours passed thus, and she was so happy that she did not notice that the ship was sailing away.

After she had seen the last thing she thanked the merchant and prepared to go home; but when she came to the ship's side she saw that they were on the high seas, far from land, and that the ship was speeding on its way under full canvas.
Oh!, I am deceived, carried away and betrayed into the power of a merchant; I would rather have died!

I am no merchant, but a king of as high birth as yourself; and it was my great love for you that made me carry you off by stratagem. The first time I saw your likeness I fell to the ground in a swoon.
When the Princess of the Golden Roof heard this she was comforted, and her heart went out to him, so that she willingly consented to become his wife.
# 3 ravens
Now it happened one day, while they were sailing on the high seas, that Trusty John, sitting on the forepart of the ship, fiddling away to himself, observed three ravens in the air flying toward him.
left_text: I will pretend that I don't notice them
right_text: I'll hide and wait to see what they do

text:
Ah, ha! so he's bringing the Princess of the Golden Roof home
Yes, but he's not got her yet
Yes, he has, for she's sitting beside him on the ship
left_text: It's my imagination, ravens can't talk
right_text: wait and listen

text: That'll not help him! When they reach the land a chestnut horse will dash forward to greet them: the King will wish to mount it, and if he does it will gallop away with him, and disappear into the air, and he will never see his bride again
left_text: I'm not going to listen to some birds
right_text: listen more

text:
Is there no escape for him?
Oh! yes, if someone else mounts quickly and shoots the horse dead with the pistol that is sticking in the holster, then the young King is saved. But who's to do that? And anyone who knows it and tells him will be turned into stone from his feet to his knees
left_text: This is all nonsense
right_text: stand still and listen

text: I know more than that: even if the horse is slain, the young King will still not keep his bride: when they enter the palace together they will find a ready-made wedding shirt in a cupboard, which looks as though it were woven of gold and silver, but is really made of nothing but sulphur and tar: when the King puts it on it will burn him to his marrow and bones
left_text: There's no way I believe this
right_text: listen more

text:
Is there no way of escape, then?
Oh! yes! If someone seizes the shirt with gloved hands and throws it into the fire, and lets it burn, then the young King is saved. But what's the good? Anyone knowing this and telling it will have half his body turned into stone, from his knees to his heart
left_text: Even if it's true it seems to be endless
right_text: wait more

text: I know yet more: though the bridal shirt too be burnt, the King hasn't even then secured his bride: when the dance is held after the wedding, and the young Queen is dancing, she will suddenly grow deadly white, and drop down like one dead, and unless...
left_text: There's no hope in
right_text: got to hear to the end

text: someone lifts her up and draws three drops of blood from her right side, and spits them out again, she will die. But if anyone who knows this betrays it, he will be turned into stone from the crown of his head to the soles of his feet
left_text: ravens, wait, tell me what to do?
right_text: I need to think what to do

text: When the ravens had thus conversed they fled onward, but Trusty John had taken it all in, and was sad and depressed from that time forward; for if he were silent to his master concerning what he had heard, he would involve him in misfortune; but if he took him into his confidence, then he himself would forfeit his life.
left_text: Not sure what I can do
right_text: I will stand by my master, though it should be my ruin

text: # Interventions
Now when they drew near the land it came to pass just as the ravens had predicted, and a splendid chestnut horse bounded forward.
Capital! This animal shall carry me to my palace, I will mount it
left_text: seize the pistol out of the holster and shoot the horse dead
right_text: take out the sword and cut the horse down

text: What a sin to kill the beautiful beast that was to bear the King to his palace!
left_text: I remain silent
right_text: There's something you don't know

text: Silence! let him alone; he is ever my most trusty John. Who knows for what good end he may have done this thing?
left_text: I serve in silence
right_text: I know something I need to tell you

text: So they went on their way and entered the palace, and there in the hall stood a cupboard in which lay the ready-made bridal shirt, looking for all the world as though it were made of gold and silver.
The young King went toward it and was about to take hold of it
but Trusty John, pushing him aside, seized it with his gloved hands, threw it hastily into the fire, and let it burn
See, he's actually burning the King's bridal shirt
left_text: I shall remain silent
right_text: I have a secret to share

text: Who knows for what good purpose he does it? Let him alone, he is my most trusty John
left_text: Thank you for the trust, mylord
right_text: I can't hide it from you anymore

text: Then the wedding was celebrated, the dance began, and the bride joined in, but Trusty John watched her countenance carefully.
Of a sudden she grew deadly white, and fell to the ground as if she were dead.
He at once sprang hastily toward her, lifted her up, and bore her to a room, where he laid her down, and kneeling beside her he drew three drops of blood from her right side, and spat them out.
Throw John into prison. He will hanged tomorrow morning
left_text: I beg for the privelege of last words
right_text: Every one doomed to death has the right to speak once before he dies?

text: Yes, it shall be granted to you. What do you have to say of yourself?
left_text: I have nothing to say, mylord
right_text: I am unjustly condemned, I have overheard this damnation brought by three ravens

text: Oh! my most trusty John, pardon! pardon! Take him down
left_text: Uhm...

text: But as he uttered the last word your body had fallen lifeless to the ground, and was a stone
# Resurrection
Ah! how ill have I rewarded such great fidelity! Lift him and put him in my bedroom near my bed
Oh! if I could only restore you to life, my most trusty John!

After a time the Queen gave birth to twins, two small sons, who throve and grew, and were a constant joy to her. One day when the Queen was at church, and the two children sat and played with their father, he gazed again full of grief on the stone statue
Oh, if I could only restore you to life, my most trusty John!
left_text: If you cut off with your own hand the heads of your two children, and smear me with their blood, I shall come back to life
right_text: Yes, you can restore me to life again if you are prepared to sacrifice what you hold most dear

text: All I have in the world will I give up for your sake
left_text: It is the blood of your children taken by your own hand that needs to be smeared on me
right_text: If you cut off with your own hand the heads of your two children, and smear me with their blood

text: The King was aghast when he heard that he had himself to put his children to death; but when he thought of Trusty John's fidelity, and how he had even died for him, he drew his sword, and with his own hand cut the heads off his children
And when he had smeared the stone with their blood, life came back, and Trusty John stood once more safe and sound before him.
left_text: I mourn the loss of your children
right_text: Your loyalty shall be rewarded

text: Taking up the heads of the children, he placed them on their bodies, smeared the wounds with their blood, and in a minute they were all right again and jumping about as if nothing had happened.
Then the King was full of joy, and when he saw the Queen coming, he hid Trusty John and the two children in a big cupboard.
In church my thoughts dwelt constantly on Trusty John, and of what he has suffered for us
Dear wife, we can restore him to life, but the price asked is our two little sons; we must sacrifice them
My heart sinks at the thought, but we owe it to him on account of his great fidelity

Then he rejoiced that she was of the same mind as he had been, and going forward he opened the cupboard, and fetched the two children and Trusty John out, saying: "God be praised! Trusty John is free once more, and we have our two small sons again." Then he related to her all that had passed, and they lived together happily ever afterward.
left_text: Start again
right_text: Start again

text: # Non-story
She must be some kind of princess. You need to find who she is
left_text: Maybe she's from the Golden Roof?
right_text: She is the Princess of the Golden Roof

text: And so did Trusty John meet his end - in silence, but faithful to his lord
left_text: Start again
right_text: Start again

text: When the queen came back from church, the king asked her "Did you pray in church?"
Yes, but my thoughts dwelt constantly on Trusty John, and of what he has suffered for us
Dear wife, we can restore him to life, but the price asked is our two little sons; we must sacrifice them
The Queen grew white and her heart sank, but she replied: "We owe it to him on account of his great fidelity." and left the room crying

The King was aghast when he heard that he had himself to put his children to death; but when he thought of Trusty John's fidelity, and how he had even died for him, he drew his sword, and with his own hand cut the heads off his children.
And when he had smeared the stone with their blood, life came back, and Trusty John stood once more safe and sound before him.
left_text: I mourn the loss of your children
right_text: Your loyalty shall be rewarded

text: Taking up the heads of the children, he placed them on their bodies, smeared the wounds with their blood, and in a minute they were all right again and jumping about as if nothing had happened.
Good that you're back my Trusty John, but how can I live with what I have done?
left_text: I have a way to bring them back
right_text: I owe you for saving my life

text: Now when they drew near the land, a splendid chestnut horse bounded forward
left_text: What a beautiful horse
right_text: This is truly a marvelous animal

text: Capital! This animal shall carry me to my palace, I will mount it
left_text: It is a beautiful animal, Mylord
right_text: Let me help you, My King

text:
The King had not yet mounted the horse properly, it jumped wildly kicking you to death and breaking the Kings neck to the floor
Sadly so ended a story that started to beautifully
left_text: Start again
right_text: Start again

text: # The king attends to the princess and wins her heart so they sail away
Oh! my, what beautiful gold wares! Let me set down my pails, and examine your gold items one thing after the other
left_text: These are only a first gift to the princess
right_text: We have much more on our ship

text: The maiden ran back to her Princess and it was arranged that the King attends the Princess on the next day
left_text: This was exactly my plan
right_text: It must me God's will that things work this way

text: Soon after she commits her heart to the King and agrees to sail away back to his kingdom for a ceremony
left_text: Let's pray for their happiness together
right_text: I have served well my Master again
